section.title: Future forms review
section.sectiontitle: For timetables: Use the Present Simple to talk about timetables.
section.sectiontitle2: For decisions, plans and intentions: Use will to talk about a decision made at the time of speaking (including offers and promises).
section.text4a: I don't think I'll have a coffee.

section.title: Future forms review
section.sectiontitle: Use going to to talk about a plan or intention (maybe details haven't been decided yet).
section.text2a: We're not going to invite the Morrisons.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Continuous to talk about a future arrangement (details such as time and place have been decided).
section.text4a: We're not leaving until after lunch.

section.title: Future forms review
section.sectiontitle: For predictions: Use will to make predictions based on what you know/believe. We often use think, hope, believe, etc. with will in this case.
section.text1a: I think Mike will be a good manager.
section.text2a: We believe she will do a good job.
section.sectiontitle2: Use going to to make predictions based on what you can see/hear/think/feel now.
section.text3a: I think I'm going to be sick.
section.text4a: Watch out! You're going to hit that car.

section.title: Future forms review
section.sectiontitle: Use the Future Continuous to talk about something in progress at a definite time in the future.
section.text1a: This time next year I'll be living in France.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use the Future Continuous to ask about someone's plans, especially if we want something or want them to do something.

section.title: Future forms review
section.sectiontitle: Use the Future Perfect with time phrases with by, e.g. by that time, by this time next week, by the end of February, by the end of the day, etc.
section.text1a: By June we will have finished the project.
